title: Erdős Problem #468: Partial Sums of Divisors
description: Let D_n = partial sums of divisors of n (excluding 1). How large is D_n \ ⋃_{m<n} D_m? If f(N) = min{n : N ∈ D_n}, is f(N) = o(N)? Status: OPEN.

sections.title: Question 1: New Elements
sections.summary: How large is D_n minus all previous partial sum sets?

sections.title: Question 2: First Appearance
sections.summary: f(N) = min{n : N ∈ D_n}; conjectured f(N) = o(N).

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham posed this in 1980 as part of their study of divisor-related problems. The partial sums of divisors form a natural combinatorial object, but their collective behavior across all integers is poorly understood.
overview.problemStatement: Let D_n be the set of partial sums of divisors of n (excluding 1). (1) How many elements of D_n are new? (2) If f(N) = min{n : N ∈ D_n}, is f(N) = o(N)?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize D_n as partial sums of sorted divisors > 1, define the first-appearance function f(N), and state both conjectures. Small examples illustrate the construction.
keyInsights: D_n is the set of cumulative sums d₁, d₁+d₂, ... of divisors > 1
Each n contributes new partial sums not seen before
The smallest element of D_n is the least prime factor of n
f(N) = o(N) would mean most partial sums arise from relatively small n

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #468 asks about the partial sums of divisors: how many are new for each n, and how quickly does f(N) grow? Both questions remain open, connecting divisor theory to combinatorial number theory.
conclusion.implications: Understanding partial divisor sums would shed light on the additive structure of divisor sets and the distribution of arithmetic functions.
openQuestions: Is f(N) = o(N) for all N?
Is f(N) = o(N) for almost all N?
What is the density of ⋃_n D_n in ℕ?
